home.title: Homepage is boring, go and read the About page
home.textBody:
You've finally arrived at our homepage!

What have you been waiting for? Since you're here, let me show you what's this page all about. Yeah, you've read it correct, it's a page, not plural. This is a single-page application written in plain Javascript and rendered in your browser. Wonderful, right?

Meet Vanilla Javascript Router

Let me walk you through this web app.

Click on the link or use the navbar to check the About page or the Blog. Or if you just wanna see the source code, here is the link to my repo on Github.

ENJOY!

about.title: About
about.textBody:
The primary goal of this web app was to help me figure out how the router in frontend frameworks works. Plus, I wanted to build a single-page app in plain Javascript, so you see how that worked out.

Even though the main logic here happens in the browser, I had to set a simple Express server in Node.js to serve one index.html. And since I was using Node, I thought why would I hardcode content when I can use a simple JSON file as a database and serve that as well.

Building this app was difficult, but during the process I've learned quite a few things about the Browser Object Model. Also, I have deployed my first app using the Heroku platform. I didn't expect it to be this simple.

Now let's talk about routes!

This Javascript file contains all the beauty of this app.

import Home from '../views/Home.js'
import Blog from '../views/Blog.js'
import Post from '../views/Post.js'
import NotFound from '../views/NotFound.js'
import About from '../views/About.js'

const routes = [
    {
        path: '/',
        component: Home
    },
    {
        path: '/error-404',
        component: NotFound
    },
    {
        path: '/about',
        component: About
    },
    {
        path: '/blog',
        component: Blog
    },
    {
        path: '/blog/:slug',
        component: Post
    }
]

export default routes

I don't know about you, but when I find myself in a situation to work on a brand new project (talking about Vue.js), the first thing I do is check the routes.js file and use those to navigate through the app starting with views.

Additional feature

If you try to navigate from one page to another and wander through the blog page, you will probably notice that the app automatically scrolls down to the position you've previously been on. Crazy, right?! Saving the scroll position in an object within the browser was a bit tricky, but I've managed to pull that one out, too.

I just love to keep the good UX, because what kind of a frontend developer would I be if I wasn't giving a damn about it. ðŸ˜‰
